msgSnippet: ... it ... public Test1 extends TestCase public Test2 extends TestCase That s not reusing the same class:  you now have two test classes. ... No, it just
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On

> > I think the original poster wanted to reuse the same test class and pass
it
> > different parameters, which would alter its behavior.
> >
> > Hence my suggestion of the Strategy pattern.
> >
> Extending an abstract TestCase is reusing the same test class.
> Passing an instance was your solution.

public Test1 extends TestCase
public Test2 extends TestCase

That's not reusing the same class: you now have two test classes.

> Passing an instance of the class under test to the TestCase
> as a parameter introduces a dependency which prevents the
> TestCase from being run in isolation.

No, it just creates two instances of the same test class with different
parameters. Why would I create *two* test classes if their only difference
is the value of a parameter?

Imagine a test class that verifies that certain values are present in an XML
file and you want to reuse this same class to test several XML files.
Surely you won't create as many test classes as there are XML files, right?

> As another poster
> pointed out, it is also an intention revealing test design,
> as it allows the developer to test items specific to the
> implementation, while highlighting what is common to the interface.

Hence the Strategy pattern. You reuse the same class and you pass it
different strategies that slightly alter its behavior without modifying its
interface.

Think of a sort() method to which you can pass various algorithms of
sorting.
